characters: FROM INSIDE THE LOBBY, DEV WATCHES AS JILLIAN OPENS A REA
THREE-SIXTY VIEW OF THE CITY SURROUNDING THEM.
CLASPED HANDS TO DISGUISE THE HANDCUFFS ON THEIR WRISTS.
ON A PAIR OF FLORSHEIM WINGTIPS CLICKING ALONG THE SIDEWA
IN A WINDOW ON THE 14TH FLOOR, FITZ AND SLIDE WATCH AS TH
SEDAN DOOR AND GUIDES CHARLIE AND COLE INSIDE.
MUSIC KICKS IN, TRANSPORTING US TO --
-- COLE AND SLIDE EMERGE FROM A DOORWAY AND STEP OUT INTO
PLAYS AS CHARLIE AND COLE ARE LED OUT, COATS OVER THEIR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (and QUEENS, and BROOKLYN, NEWARK, STATEN ISLAND, THE BRO HARLEM, and the disappearing corners of Manhattan that un overpasses, or too close to soup kitchens to have become gentrified). (TITLE SEQUENCE) We'll see A SERIES of SHOTS of the city waking up. Except that it’s two cities: One, the sparkle-y winner-take-all Manhattan of the movie “The Apprentice,” and Eva Gabor. Two, the get-real Manhattan where the regular people, who daily sweat makes Sparkle-y Manhattan go, begin their har working day. Over the beepings/shrillings/radio blarings of various AL we see QUICK CUTS of TENEMENT PIPES shuddering as rusty w spatters onto three squirming kids in a bathtub, being hastily bathed by their bi-racial mother.. to MULTIPLE je of a WaterWorks shower pummelling the backside of a SUPERMODEL... We see ARMS going into uniform sleeves, to ARMS going int Dolce & Gabanna chemise... Dr. Scholl’s pads going into sensible shoes... manicured toes going into thousand doll platforms with six inch heels. We see name tags pinned on front pockets.... bow ties clipped onto collars... to A ROLEX being fastened around man’s wrist... back to... AN OLD GUY (LESTER) sits at the kitchen table of his Lowe East Side one bedroom, which has seen no renovation since they put in hot water in the ‘30’s. He is painstakingly SEWING A BUTTON on the sleeve of his DOORMAN’S UNIFORM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VARIOUS SHOTS of the underclasses moving towards their jobs... and their overlords perhaps going to work, perhap not. TENNIS SHOED FEET step down stairs to SUBWAY STATION MAGLI SHOED feet get out of LIMOS. AWNINGS pulled down on VENDOR CARTS... ITALIAN SILK SHADES pulled down so a RICH GIRL can go back to bed. A messenger on a bicycle is graz by a BMW. The well dressed driver zips down his window, craning his neck -- not to see if the messenger’s okay, b instead to inspect his car for scratches. Towards the gleaming towers of Midtown, the employed underclass is walking, walking... .-. from the other direction walk a couple of CLUBBING R KIDS, still in their party clothes, having been out all night... +. Hardhats edge around them, just trying to get the hell their jobs.. .+.. PAMPERED DOG PAWS are also walking. TILT UP TO REVEA One person walking is a uniformed black man, 30's, MR. WASHINGTON. He is walking SIX pedigreed DOGS in front of SLEEK, STATE OF THE ART MODERN LUXURY BUILDING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 60’s/EARLY 70's HEIST ENERGY, WE COULD DO A WINDOWPANE SC

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YORKERS... from satellite dishes on cardboard boxes to helipads on buildings... you get the idea...) One of the dogs slips its leash! A silky AFGHAN makes a break for freedom, dashing down the sidewalk as, coming around the corner, we see--

dialogues.speaker: 5TH AVENUE/59TH STREET N R W
dialogues.text: COLE HOWARD, on one side or the other of 40. He takes in tableau at a glance -- the screaming dog-walker trying to catch up, the bounding Afghan. In a swift move, Cole plunks down 2 dollars on a vendor's cart and grabs a small SHISH KEBAB, waving it at the dog’ eye level. The hound stops instantly, practically levitat to get the meat, as MR. WASHINGTON, the dog walker, catch up.

dialogues.speaker: MR. WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Mr. Howard -- ahhh, thanks --

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Carry a stash of treats, Mr. Washington -- you’re competing with every enticing smell in Manhattan. Cole goes into the building. Mr. Washington watches after him, nodding.

dialogues.speaker: MR. WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Yeah, aren’t we all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LESTER, the old doorman, now in full uniform, smiles at C the Residence Manager, as he strides in, clearly in charg the place.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Morning, Lester.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: Looking to be a fine day, Mr. Howard. FROM A HIGH ANGLE, LOOKING DOWN on Cole, and for the firs time we catch a glimpse of this building: sleek, modern, jewel of the block. ABOVE A STAFF ENTRANCE, a security camera peers down. ON PLASMA SECURITY MONITOR, DISPLAYING NUMEROUS ANGLES: Cole shoots a salute to the camera and -- BUZ2Z2Z2ZZZ! --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- he’s admitted inside. Cole pushes on down the corridor passing maids, porters, attendants -- offering each a friendly, firm smile.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Morning. Morning, Miss Lewis, your son better? Good. Mr. Stuart, there’re some Vodka bottles on the roof deck... school’s obviously out... Mrs. Lopez, the elevator’s reeking--! The STOUT HISPANIC JANITRESS nods vigorously, rolling her eyes. She holds up an ANTISCEPTIC SPRAY BOTTLE: she’s on

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LOPEZ
dialogues.text: You don’t got to tell me! The cheap cologne on that guy, oh my God!

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Miss Lopez. Residents’ guests who wear miniskirts are women, until we are otherwise instructed. She nods. Knows he’s right. He pokes his head inside--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: where a GUARD mans the monitors. Cole points at a DARK CA on the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What’s with the tinted windows across the street?

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Don’t know. Been there all night.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Keep an eye. It’s not your typical towncar. CHARLIE GIBBS, concierge, Cole’s age, falls into stride w him. They’ve been ten years on the job together.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Morning.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Mr. Gibbs.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What’d you do this weekend?

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Worried about this place.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Y’know it is our 10 year anniversary. Think you could start calling me Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: (only half joking) And that’s the beginning of the end. Next it’ll be “bro” and “Dude,” and the discipline around here’‘1l go straight to hell. Even talking about it opens a crack into the abyss. They enter--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The most elegant, most comfortable private lobby in NYC. three-story high ceiling with a glass wall filling the sp with light. A cherry-oak-paneled concierge’s counter topp with Egyptian marble. Designer divans and reading chairs galore and a zen fountain. Charlie points towards the front door, at LESTER, the doo we saw earlier. Well into his 70s, he knows no greater pleasure than doing his job well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about him? A GAGGLE of KIDS swarm through the lobby, off to school. Cole knows all their names. Their favorite, however, is Lester: he’s a giant teddy bear to them.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: Who did their homework for today? Whatya mean no homework today?! Why not?! Oh, cause it’s the first day of school!! ... Lester opens the door for the kids. They rush out.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: What about him?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You call Lester, Lester.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: I prefer Lester to you. Cole pats Charlie on the shoulder and goes -- he obviousl likes Charlie enough to bust his balls. (And we will soon see that he is actually more informal with Charlie than anyone in the place.) The lobby is coming to life, now. All staff wear an earpi and a mic clipped to their sleeve, except Cole who keeps slender walkie in his breast pocket.

dialogues.speaker: COLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Everyone awake? Okay, service with a smile. The staff, at their stations, nod back. ELEVATOR DOORS OPEN AND AN OVERLY BEJEWELED WOMAN EXITS. Cole is there to welcome her; today’s performance has beg She doesn’t break stride, just starts barking “favors.”

dialogues.speaker: BEJEWELED WOMAN
dialogues.text: Cole, my day today is a ballbuster. At ten a man’s coming from Pierre Laveurre to measure for my valances... then the TV lift bandits are coming, again -- it’s still having these epileptic seizures-- Thus begins A MONTAGE OF COLE’S MORNING. He is a master handling each resident: he compliments, he cajoles, with children he clowns, to older residents he kowtows. As he accepts each resident “request,” Charlie keeps a discreet do list at his desk.

dialogues.speaker: VARIOUS RESIDENTS
dialogues.text: +.-pick up my dry-cleaning/... move the armoire/ stir the confit/appraise the Monet.../...feed the finches/...the moth larvae will have to be picked, nit by nit, off those sweaters/... Cole’s just as good with staff. Later, eying some NEW, PETITE SIZED LINGERIE on a rack, he delegates to a PORTER

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: .--ah, ah, no -- not to the apartment, to Mr. Davis's office... (low) -. Mrs. Davis is a size 12. Cole talks a mile a minute into his mouthpiece, directing redirecting building traffic. COLE (CONT’D) .--It’s 7:45 and I’m still seeing laundry carts. You should all be on your way... Mr. Hutensky, Mrs. Simon is still missing her Mercedes key. -- Well, that dog does eat just about anything, I’m afraid you’re going to have to do some... panning for gold. Miss Hahn, be aware, the windows in 66B have been removed, try not to plunge to your deaths... Under Cole’s running patter we see MORE MONTAGE: VARIOUS SHOTS of the minute details that makes running a full ser luxury building so complex: Beds made/plants watered/a Ve Flytrap plant fed meat/BROWN HANDS picking up JEWELRY off dresser and dusting the dresser before meticulously repla the jewelry, unmolested... MAIDS in OVERCOATS even vacuum 66B, an apartment that’s A CONSTRUCTION SITE, freezing wi blowing in through the gaping holes where the windows are still missing. AT THE PACKAGE STATION a pert Hispanic girl, PEREZ, discreetly reads a book. Suddenly, in her earpiece:  COLE’S VOICE Miss Perez--? (as she jumps) For six months I’ve pretending not to notice you've been studying for the bar. Please don’t make it so obvious that the residents notice too. She blushes, nods, and better buries her books, grateful his lenience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two guards continue to stare, on screen, at the myste parked car. COLE’S VOICE ...Steve, Miguel, has it moved?

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: No sir! (clicking off, turns to friend) What’s he going so crazy for? Has this building ever been hit?

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Shit, no.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: It’s probably just some guy getting a blow job.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: For a day and a half?

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Maybe he’s 80. They laugh. MONTAGE CONTINUES: Cole besieged by residents (The first is a stringy, edgy, rich woman, Miss Hollingsworth. We will be seeing her again.)

dialogues.speaker: HOLLINGSWORTH/VARIOUS RESIDENTS
dialogues.text: Make sure Mother takes her Lexapro AND her Atavin -- one without the other she behaves like a Chimpanzee/... (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .-+.Strange clicking noises on line one -- it could be my ex husband wiretapping me back.../ .--balloons, streamers and a pinata which can’t have candy with peanuts or her little best friend will die on the spot.... The CAMERA JUMPS BACK from Cole, handling 11 things at on BACK to a long shot of the lobby, BACK to the exterior of building, looking in, BACK from ACROSS THE STREET... Someone, with very professional equipment, is watching th building through a telephoto lens. TITLE-UP: T O W E R H E Is T

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole finally has a moment to breathe. But ever vigilant, looks around.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: --So where’s our new elevator man...? Isn’t he starting today?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Looks like he’s jumped the gun. He gestures at THE ELEVATOR BANK, where ARTHUR BRANIFF, 6 gets off the elevator, MR. DEV’REAUX, dapper in his new uniform, happily chatting while manning the elevator. Despite his $200 haircut and hand-tailored dress shirt an Caribbean tan, Braniff is a master at getting people to forget Fitzgerald’s maxim about the rich ("They're differ than you and me”).

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR BRANIFF
dialogues.text: Well, Jamal, nice t’ meecha. DEV’ REAUX Pleasure, sir! Cole turns to Charlie, nonplussed.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: “Jamal?”

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Told a resident his first name...?! Uh uh uh. Cole wants to yank Dev’reaux aside, but Braniff seems to enjoying the encounter, so Cole keeps a smile on his face a moment more.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR BRANIFF
dialogues.text: Jamaal, has Cole taught you the golden rule of working here yet?

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: (shooting daggers at Deveraux) We haven’t actually run Mr. Devr’eaux through the protocol...

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR BRANIFF
dialogues.text: Jamaal, if I asked you, would you go pick me up a cheeseburger?

dialogues.speaker: DEV ' REAUX
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR BRANIFF
dialogues.text: Thing is, I want a certain kind of brie on my burger they only sell at Michel’s cheese shop downtown. Think you can get that first?

dialogues.speaker: DEV ' REAUX
dialogues.text: Certainly, Mr. Braniff.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR BRANIFF
dialogues.text: As for the hamburger, only organically-fed, free-range beef, please. Can you make sure of that?

dialogues.speaker: DEV ' REAUX
dialogues.text: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR BRANIFF
dialogues.text: Finally the buns. This is the most important part. I need the buns blessed by the pope himself. See to it, willya?

dialogues.speaker: DEV ' REAUX
dialogues.text: (catching on) Got the Vatican on speed-dial.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR BRANIFF
dialogues.text: He’s a natural. (to Dev) Always say yes. That’s the golden rule. Say yes, then figure out how the hell you’re gonna manage it. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR BRANIFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I may live at the top of this building but I’m in the service industry same as you and Cole, and I know soon as I say ‘no’ toa customer, I’m flat-out on my ass. Braniff gives Dever’aux a $100 bill. ARTHUR BRANIFF (CONT’D) Another thing, Jamaal: I do everything myself. Keeps me honest. I’1ll get my own cheeseburger, and you get one too, on me! As Braniff wanders off, Dever’aux’s suddenly sees--

dialogues.speaker: LOBBY SEATING AREA
dialogues.text: A copy of NEWSWEEK is casually splayed across the coffee table, a PICTURE of ARTHUR BRANIFF on the COVER! Dev’raux doubletakes, staring at the photo, as Cole steps into fra beside him. DEVER ‘ AUX Wow. He’s pretty real for... (picks up magazine) .-.”The Wall Street Wizard?!”

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Mr. Dever’aux, as you can see, some of our residents are pretty high profile individuals. What made you think you should jump in without any orientation?

dialogues.speaker: MR. DEVERAUX
dialogues.text: Well, pushing buttons, shooting the breeze, I mean -- I know the job. Charlie and Cole exchange a look.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Remind me: where did we steal you away from?

dialogues.speaker: DEV ' REAUX
dialogues.text: Spent the last two years at the Richelieu on 78th.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: That’s a good building. Why'd you want to leave it?  11.

dialogues.speaker: DEV ' REAUX
dialogues.text: You wanna play baseball, you gonna wanna play someday for the Yankees. This building’s the Yankees.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: (not unkindly) Then don’t treat it like the sand lot. “Pushing buttons” and “shooting the breeze” is seriously demeaning your job. You are crucial to these people: you are part of protecting them.

dialogues.speaker: DEV ' REAUX
dialogues.text: From what, sir? Cole gestures across the lobby, where Arthur Braniff has stopped by an anxious-looking MIDDLE AGED GUY in a SUIT. This is FITZHUGH.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: He’s gone ten steps, and he’s already under attack from Mr. Fitzhugh over there, a much less successful money manager who’s desperate for tips. Mr. Gibbs, head him off, please... Charlie quickly speeds off to stop this encounter. Mr. FITZHUGH is already in mid-pitch.

dialogues.speaker: MR. FITZHUGH
dialogues.text: --I did try your office, but everything’s on voice mail -- if you could just -- one millisecond -- see, I’m having a hell of a time locking down even a safe 2% return in this market, and any suggestion... just the wisp of a hint... would really help me out of a ...well, verging on catastrophic-- He sees Charlie coming, who is shooting daggers at him. Quickly, to Braniff:

dialogues.speaker: MR. FITZHUGH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you! We’1ll reconvene soon! He scurries off. Charlie sighs to Braniff.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Mr. Howard apologizes. He got past us.  12.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR BRANIFF
dialogues.text: I can’t really blame Fitzhugh. He’s losing his apartment. (sighs) Tough times make civilized people do uncivilized things. Braniff shrugs affably and goes. Meanwhile, across the lobby, Cole continues to brief Mr. Dev’reaux.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: After the doorman admits a visitor, you're their second line of defense. And your antenna should be out at all times for anyone going up in your car who gives you even the smallest uneasy feeling... His eye drifts towards... EXT. THROUGH THE LOBBY FRONT GLASS - COLE’S POV - DAY The TINTED WINDOW CAR still sits, mysteriously, across th street. Two OVERCOATED MEN walk past.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Like those two. He walks outside, Lester opening the door, Dever’aux at h heels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole watches the men continue down the street, then turns Dev’reaux, explaining.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: That’s the second time they’ve walked by the building from the same direction. May be nothing, but it’s a little off.

dialogues.speaker: DEV ' REAUX
dialogues.text: Man. Not even your job, but you notice everything!

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: It’s all my job. There’s a cellular structure to a full service building -- in order to keep this hive running we all exceed our job descriptions. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: COLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: These residents won’t notice ordinary service -- only the extraordinary service will get you that bonus. Cole gives the building’s perimeter a once-over. He spies scrap of trash at the curb and squats to pick it up. Dev’reaux just stares. That's dedication.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tarp covering the absent window on 66 flaps in the wind the sun goes down. Below, Mr. Washington exits the staff entrance, in his civvies, knocking off for the night. He passes MISS HOLLINGSWORTH, the stringy, nasty woman we met earlier.

dialogues.speaker: MR. WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Evening, Miss. Hollingsworth. (the woman startles) --It’s just me, Mr. Washington.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HOLLINGSWORTH
dialogues.text: Oh! Oh.

dialogues.speaker: MR. WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Out of uniform. Got it. He keeps his expression cheerful, but drops it the minute goes on her way. Racist bitch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON A CHECK: “Alimony -- September.” Cole’s mailing his monthly dues as Charlie, in civvies now, raps on the door Exiting, Cole and Charlie pass the LOCKER ROOM. Cole lean in to kill the light, to find Lester still here, gazing i space.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Lester? You okay?

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: .+.-jJust gettin’ my shoes on... I'll be outta here in a jiff... Cole eyes Lester, knows the old man has something on his mind.  14.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: What.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: Naw, it’s a long day for you, Mr. Howard... Cole smiles.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: And now it’s over, and I have time. What.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: It’s just, ah... I uh, I asked Mr. Simon a few weeks ago to get me some funds from my 401 thing -- (quickly) --not playin’ the horses or anything, Mr. Howard -- my little grandkids out in California, their daddy got laid off, and they're feeling the pinch, you know--

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: For you to even bring it up, it’s more than a pinch.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: Well, they’re behind kinda every which way...

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Losing their house?

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: (sighs) Yeah, if I don’t help...

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Of course, why wouldn’t you help?

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: Well, that’s just it... Mr. Simon, he hasn’t given me the money.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: When did you ask him?

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: Six weeks ago.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: And you still don't have the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says that the bank’s gonna get to it.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Well you're -- (not wanting to guess Lester’s age) --of a certain age, you can take that money out. This makes no sense at all.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: Banks get busy, like anybody.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Not with our pension plan. INT. THE TOWER -- MR. SIMON’S OFFICE -- DAY 15. Doorplate: “PROPERTY MANAGER.” Mr. Simon sits and peruses Wall Street Journal a moment before he addresses Cole.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SIMON
dialogues.text: The economy’s in the crapper, Cole.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: With all due respect, sir, I don’t really see how that entitles a bank to stall giving Lester some of his money.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SIMON
dialogues.text: Everyone’s cutting staff.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Then the remaining bank employees can work free overtime, as we do. There is a subtle dig there, but Cole keeps his pleasant and professional.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SIMON
dialogues.text: Don’t get smart. The resident board thinks we may have some staff redundancies.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Whoa, Whoa: cut OUR staff? My people are out there busting their--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: expression  16.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SIMON
dialogues.text: (raises a hand: enough) I just want to prepare you for possible contingencies. Mr. Simon simply picks up his newspaper and starts readin The interview is over. MR. SIMON (CONT’D) Hang up the Christmas tapestry tomorrow, please.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: It’s already done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole, Charlie and Lester exit the building together, head to their various homes. Cole notices: the tinted window c is still sitting there. And -- across the street -- there

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: There’s two of them, now? Why haven't they been towed?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (shrugs ) Call the city.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: We did. They’re doing nothing -- no, really, it makes no sense -- Cole finally lets Charlie pull him along, down the sidewa walking along with Lester, pleased to have company. At a stop, they wait with Lester for his crosstown, Cole tryin not to flick a glance back at the mystery cars.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: -- the littlest one tells me the other day on the phone: “Grandpa, what’s invisible and smells like worms?” “Bird farts,” he says. The way he laughed at his own joke I just about died.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: You ever think about moving out there?  17.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: Nah. I can help ‘em out more from here, and no use pretending I don’t love the job...

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Lester. The day you go, we change the name of the building, cause it’1l never be the same. Nothing could mean more to Lester. His bus arrives.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: Night, Mr. Howard. Mr. Gibbs.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Lester, outside the building...? It’s just Cole. Charlie drops his jaw. He’s never seen Cole give that permission to anyone. They watch Lester step aboard, then proceed to the subway. INT. CHET AND MARTY’S LIVING ROOM - NIGHT All that is mundane and lower middle class in Queens. The house is festooned with cheap BIRTHDAY BALLOONS AND STREAMERS. MARTY, Cole’s mother, 60’s, sympathetic and ki if a bit timid, admits Cole, who is holding a PRESENT.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Hey, Mom. (peers inside) Where’s Dad?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: In his office.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: It’s his birthday.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: (sighs) It’s tax time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole stands in the doorway, looking in at his father, WAL an accountant, looking dutiful and harried, up to his eyeballs in his clients’ TAX RETURNS.  18.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Dad. You coming out?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Yeah, I will... And he means it. He wants to. It’s just.. so much work.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Brought you something. He enters the office, places the present on his Dad’s des Walt unwraps it.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Oh, hey, great, an organizer!

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: I know your old one’s a little frayed. Cole smiles, glad his present pleases. Marty appears behi him.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Walt, you gotta give it half an hour. Walt sighs. He wants to go to his own birthday party; he really does. He gets up, feeling torn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People are toasting and mingling around a nervous looking Walt. He can’t stop thinking about that pile of paper on desk.

dialogues.speaker: SLIDE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey, here’s my present, Mr. H. SLIDE is a sharp-looking black man, about Cole’s age, a little too flashily dressed for a modest birthday party. However, he seems very comfortable with these people. He hands Walt an iPhone, out of a satchel in which Cole can - there are about 20 of them, all in their original boxes Walt is very fond of Slide, but is immediately suspicious

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Do you have a receipt for this?  19.

dialogues.speaker: SLIDE
dialogues.text: Ah, now, we’re not gonna start that--!

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: No, really, Darnell--!

dialogues.speaker: SLIDE
dialogues.text: Shit, nobody call me that now--

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Well, we just can’t help remembering the old days...! There are PICTURES on the wall of kindergarden buds, 5 YE OLD SLIDE and 5 YEAR OLD COLE, with their arms around eac other.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: He’s been Slide for a while, Mom. Cole and Slide appraise each other and smile, two old fri whose lives have gone in entirely different directions.

dialogues.speaker: COLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: SLIDE
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: You don’t still live around here...?

dialogues.speaker: SLIDE
dialogues.text: Nah. Got a soft spot for your old Dad.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Yeah, well. He was around.

dialogues.speaker: SLIDE
dialogues.text: There’s that. Slide’s clearly wasn’t.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: What have you been doing --? Slide just laughs. COLE (CONT’D) Okay. Never mind.  20. Cole looks around, notices the house is all torn up. Most notably, the kitchen. Like, they’re cooking on a HOT PLAT

dialogues.speaker: COLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gawd, Mom -- they’re still not finished?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: A coupla permits didn’t come through.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: But you applied two years ago.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Man says we gotta wait.

dialogues.speaker: SLIDE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You don’t gotta wait. I just did mine, and... last time the city came around, I just... made a contribution.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: To..?

dialogues.speaker: SLIDE
dialogues.text: Their well being.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: That’s generally called “taxes.” The word “taxes” just convulses Slide. Walt, Marty and Co are taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: SLIDE
dialogues.text: Oh, sorry, sorry, no disrepect.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Hey, seriously, Slide. Just curious, really -- I mean, why wouldn’t you want to pay for schools and roads and police protection--

dialogues.speaker: SLIDE
dialogues.text: You feel protected by the police?

dialogues.speaker: SLIDE
dialogues.text: Educated by the schools? (to Cole) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: SLIDE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I notice you in hock up to you ass to pay for that fancy-ass college -- tax dollars weren’t there to help you then. You still paying that off? We see on Cole’s face: he is.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Ah, but I would never, ever have the job that I have--

dialogues.speaker: SLIDE
dialogues.text: No, you right, you right. You got a good job. Slide means it. He respects Cole.

dialogues.speaker: SLIDE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yeah. I know. There’s days I envy that job of yours. His PHONE starts to ring. And ring. Cole looks down. The control line flashes THE TOWERS.

dialogues.speaker: SLIDE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This ain’t one of ‘em. ‘C’mon, let’s get a beer... Cole is torn. He wants to go with Slide, needs to answer.

dialogues.speaker: SLIDE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You got to get that?

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: No... It stops ringing. Immediately starts again. Marty looks a him.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Honey..? We’re about to cut the cake. Don’t. Cole looks around the room at his family, who’s watching He sighs.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: I won’t leave. Okay? I promise. (answering, into phone) Yeah.  22.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Cole sits in the back seat, cab racing along, practically levitating with anxiety. He is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Nonono -- exactly WHAT. Did you see. --Why aren’t they there? When did you call them. What kind of response time is that? --Well, how they can take that position, that nothing’s actually happened, when there’s bulges under the coats of men who have been staking out my building and they’re taking up positions around the perimeter-- what happened to crime prevention?! -- Okay, I’m here, get out front,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cab screeches up and Cole jumps out, met by THREE SECURITY GUARDS.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Okay, where are they? The guards look around.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: I don’t see ‘em now. But when the wind blew their coats against them, you could see it -- they’re definitely packing. Cole notices: the TINTED WINDOW CAR IS NOW ACROSS THE STR -- right IN FRONT of his building.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: God damn it -- enough! He marches up to the car, starts banging on the windows.

dialogues.speaker: WANT
dialogues.text: No response. Cole rushes into the lobby.  23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole races up to the NIGHT DESK MAN, agitated.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Okay, no one comes in, all right? Not until I find out who these jokers are and what they want.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT DESK MAN
dialogues.text: What about, goes out?

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: No one goes out.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT DESK MAN
dialogues.text: Cause the Mink Brinks is here. Do I not let them go out?

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: What? They came yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT DESK MAN
dialogues.text: They’re here now too.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: They’re in the garage? Now?

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT DESK MAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, they forgot to take Mr. Braniff’s wife’s mink to storage. He’s bringing it down to them.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT DESK MAN
dialogues.text: He does everything himself. Cole wheels on the guards.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Down down down--! Go down and see what the hell’s going on?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole races in:

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Garage! Mink Brinks! Find it!  24. The guy clicks around on the cameras until an IMAGE of th BRINKS TRUCK can be seen. TWO GUYS are opening the back. They are casually dressed.

dialogues.speaker: COLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Zoom in on them. I don’t know them. Zoom in on the shoes! The technician obeys. Their SHOES are EXPENSIVE ITALIAN LEATHER.

dialogues.speaker: COLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Italian leather with TASSLES?! I DON’T THINK SO. -- MAYDAY!! Oh shit-- He now sees, on camera, ARTHUR BRANIFF HIMSELF approachin the truck, helpfully carrying HIS WIFE’S MINK, sheathed i opaque thick PLASTIC. Cole shrieks into his mouthpiece:

dialogues.speaker: COLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where are you two--?! I think it’s a kidnapping! He races for the elevators.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE GUARDS rush out of the elevators. Braniff is nowhere be seen. The truck’s doors are closed, and the truck is beginning to pull away.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Truck’s moving! COLE’S VOICE Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: We don’t see him! COLE’S VOICE Oh God -- they got him! INT. ELEVATOR -- ON COLE... .»-pacing like a caged animal.  25.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Don’t open those doors! Mr. Morgan, how strong is a Brinks truck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guard, to his horror, watches as the truck BATTERS th closed gate like a battering ram, almost decimating it. T truck backs up for another try...

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Strong. The elevator opens. Cole rushes out, as the TRUCK SURGES FORWARD, SMASHING the grate!

dialogues.speaker: SHOOT OUT THE TIRES
dialogues.text: The guards start blasting. The truck SMASHES through. No way to tell if it’s hit. The three men rush to the exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brinks truck, all its right tires shot out, is fatall leaning on one side. It limps forward, SCRAPING the side the building, making sparks. Cole and the guards race towards it with everything they' got. They're gaining. The truck’s slowing. Before it stop the DRIVER and HELPER jump out and run for it. Cole and the guards have more important matters. They rac to the now-stopped truck. Cole gestures to Guard #1 to sh out the lock. He obeys. The men wrestle the door open... And there, looking very shocked, is ARTHUR BRANIFF.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Mr. Braniff--! Sir -- ! He leaps up to help Braniff, who is four shades of grey. turns and quietly VOMITS into a corner.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Did he hit a mink?  26.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: (looking around) There’s no minks. Suddenly TWO TINTED WINDOWED CARS squeal into the alley, blocking off both avenues of escape! Cole and the Guards freeze. Who are these people?! MEN get out of the cars with GUNS DRAWN. Two of them are same men Cole saw earlier -- passing his building. Twice. Cole and his guards are now seriously outnumbered. They freeze, terrified. The men draw guns. The LEAD AGENT, female, attractive in down-to-business way, 30's, flips a badge.

dialogues.speaker: FBI.
dialogues.text: Cole doesn’t get it.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT DENHAM
dialogues.text: We have a warrant for this man’s arrest. Braniff looks astonished. Cole is immediately protective.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: This man is not one of the perpetrators -- he’s the victim of an attempted kidnapping --

dialogues.speaker: AGENT DENHAM
dialogues.text: This was not a kidnapping. It was an attempt to flee.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Flee from what?! You are making a serious mistake, and against one of my residents--

dialogues.speaker: AGENT DENHAM
dialogues.text: He’1ll be residing at Rikers-- Braniff throws up his hands, conciliatory.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR BRANIFF
dialogues.text: All right, all right. We’ll get this straightened out. (to Cole) Would you mind telling my wife to call Marty Klein? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR BRANIFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tell her not to cry, it’s the FBI, not the Gestapo. Oh, and -- He hands Cole the plastic-wrapped coat. ARTHUR BRANIFF (CONT’D) Take her her mink. She’1ll worry. Cole reaches out to take the wrapped coat. The female age immediately SNATCHES IT out of his hands.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Is this a shakedown? How can you people possibly use a mink coat as eviden-- The agent ZIPS THE PLASTIC OPEN. There is no mink inside the plastic. Instead, hanging neatly, are SEVERAL PLASTIC POUCHES of various sizes, containing toiletries, thick envelopes, and reams of documents. Cole’s jaw drops. Arthur sighs impatiently. The agent zips open a compartment, pulls out a PASSPORT, flips it open. It has Arthur’s face on it, but not his na The other agents pull CASH and DOCUMENTS out of the other envelopes.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR BRANIFF
dialogues.text: This proves nothing.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT DENHAM
dialogues.text: Yeah. I guess everybody puts fake passports, account numbers and wads of Euros in mothball storage. I know I do. (to Braniff, “charming”) Walk with us. The agents cuff him and lead him down the alley, where Co can see SCADS OF REPORTERS and a few POLICE waiting, flashbulbs already popping.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: The underground exit might be more discreet.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT DENHAM
dialogues.text: Oh no. Mr. Braniff’s getting the full perp-walk. Cole volunteers his jacket to be laid over Braniff’s cuff  28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crowd has gathered outside along with a NEWS CREW to document Braniff’s walk of shame. Agent Denham escorts hi to a squad car, loading him into the rear seat. She retur Cole’s jacket and Cole looks from her to Braniff, not sur what to believe. The police caravan pulls away and Cole steers Mrs. Braniff away from cameras. SUSAN BRANIFF, a facelifted and pampered 60, bursts from front of the building, a MINK COAT over her nightgown.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN BRANIFF
dialogues.text: Arthur! What is all this?! He’s done nothing wrong! Agent Denham gets a load of her.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT DENHAM
dialogues.text: Looks like her mink’s safe. INT. COLE’S LIVING ROOM - NIGHT - CLOSE ON -—- A fistful of Advil being shaken into Cole’s hand. The appropriate ending to an awful day. His apartment lacks a woman’s touch and housekeeper’s vis On a mantel, evidence of a former life: a wedding photo. Cole sits, eating Kung Pao chicken out of a counter, gloo watching TV. His phone rings. INT. SIMON’S LIVING ROOM - NIGHT There are many, many tchockies and two little yapping dog Simon is evidently prissy. He is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SIMON
dialogues.text: What the-- INT. COLE’S LIVING ROOM Cole holds the phone away from his ear. MR. SIMON’S VOICE --HELL happened?!

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: We don’t know anything beyond the arrest. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: COLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Five news crews still parked outside, I imagine we’ll find out when they do. Cole suddenly sits bolt upright, his attention captured b the TV.

dialogues.speaker: COLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sh! Turn on channel four now!

dialogues.speaker: THE TV
dialogues.text: Braniff is the top story.

dialogues.speaker: CNBC ANCHOR, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: ...last year Wall Street titan Arthur Braniff was the subject of a 60 Minutes profile but this afternoon he's the subject of an FBI indictment. We haven't learned the charges against him...

dialogues.speaker: MR. SIMON
dialogues.text: Did he murder someone? Rape someone? He better not’ve done it in the building.

dialogues.speaker: CNBC ANCHOR
dialogues.text: ..-but there is heavy speculation that he will be charged with several counts of securities fraud...

dialogues.speaker: MR. SIMON
dialogues.text: What kind of fraud?

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Securities fraud. Swindling.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SIMON
dialogues.text: Ah, no no no NOOOO--!

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: I know. He seemed like a good guy.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SIMON
dialogues.text: Fuck that! He runs our BOARD!

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, somebody else will step in.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SIMON
dialogues.text: He manages the building’s assets!  30. Cole stares at the receiver. He never thought about that.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Manages, as in... invests? He hears only CURSING from the receiver. COLE (CONT’D) Mr. Simon, are we talking about the funds for potted palms in the lobby, or...? There’s no answer from Mr. Simon.

dialogues.speaker: OR--
dialogues.text: Mr. Simon snorts with disdain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Sun comes up over the gleaming midtown buildings..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole comes in, pensive, the weight of the world on his shoulders. He looks around the lobby, at all the people w work for him. Porters decorate the holiday TREE; it’s days before Chris and the lobby bustles with activity -- DELIVERY MEN hauli in fir trees, RESIDENTS returning with shopping, OTHERS leaving on holiday with piles upon piles of luggage. DEV’ REAUX (overloaded with ski bags) -- where you folks headed for the break? St. Moritz?! (with a bit of edge) Get outta here, that’s where I ski! The holiday music grates in Cole’s ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole has THE ENTIRE STAFF assembled. This is the hardest moment of his life.  31.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: The press hasn’t made this announcement yet, but the arresting agent was good enough to take my call and fill me in. I didn’t want any of you to hear this from some... impersonal source. (a deep breath) It seems that... Mr. Braniff’s great success was actually a giant Ponzi scheme. Anyone who had anything invested with Mr. Braniff... (beat) ...-has probably been defrauded. Murmurs of shock from the staff. Cole soldiers on, hating having to tell them all this. COLE (CONT’D) As your pensions were invested with Mr. Braniff... We PAN across the devastated faces of the MAIDS, VALETS.. and Lester. Poor Lester, who is doing his best to remain stoic in these desperate circumstances.

dialogues.speaker: MAID
dialogues.text: So that means... These are the hardest words Cole will ever have to say:

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: It’s all gone. More murmurs. They can’t believe it. Cole continues, with all the compassionate dignity he can summon.

dialogues.speaker: COLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Some of you may need some time to process this... and I will make myself available to answer any further questions... if I can. And anyone who absolutely needs to go home for the day, I will do my best to operate with a skeleton crew. I appreciate anyone staying who possibly can... but I can’t in good conscience expect that from you, in light of... what you must be feeling. If you could just tell me... who needs to go...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He scans their stunned faces. They all want to raise thei hands and leave. Some of them are blinking back tears.

dialogues.speaker: MS. PEREZ
dialogues.text: Is your pension gone too, Mr. Howard?

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Well. Yes. I’m sure it is. Of course it is, I-- A couple of them start to raise their hands, then, exchan glances with the others (who aren’t) put their hands back down. Lester dabs at his eyes, but pulls himself together, mustering a heartbreaking smile.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: Wouldn’t want to leave you short- handed, Mr. Howard. Slowly they all dissemble, go back to their posts. Cole watches them go, knowing he’s just been witness to a major act of bravery, of loyalty. He has never been so touched in his life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Svickhar approaches Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: SVICHKAR
dialogues.text: Mr. Howard gonna be out soon?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: SVICHKAR
dialogues.text: The Grinch is here. He indicates outside where --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- another caravan approaches, with a trail of news truck One crew is on the street already taping:  33.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER ON STREET
dialogues.text: “,..jJust an hour ago State Superior Court released Arthur Braniff on ten million dollars bail on condition that he remain under house arrest here at his penthouse apartment on 5th Avenue...” Agent Denham is first out of a sedan, followed by Braniff hands unbound this time. He’s assaulted with questions fr the press. Fighting through them, he stops to declare:

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR BRANIFF
dialogues.text: Yes, mistakes were made. People lost money. I’m sick about that. But they were mistakes, made with the best intentions. And I’m truly sorry they were made.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie, Ms. Perez, and Dev watch Braniff from inside.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (bitterly quoting Braniff) “Tough times makes civilized people do uncivilized things.” Braniff comes in out of the media storm, along with his w and lawyer and a phalanx of FBI agents. Cole turns to his employees:

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: I know what you’re thinking: how dare they make us his jailers. You’1l think about spitting in his coffee and overwaxing his floor. But this is the Towers, and we will remain consummate professionals. This is also America, and he’s innocent until proven guilty. The hostile clamor of the crowd outside is replaced by an silence inside as Braniff finds himself face-to-face with Tower staff.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR BRANIFF
dialogues.text: Hello, everyone. Sorry about the circus out there... No one responds. Cole, keeping his tone neutral, tries to set a good example.  34.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Mr. Braniff. Welcome home.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR BRANIFF
dialogues.text: Thanks, Cole. Good to be back. Braniff sounds like the same genial guy he ever was. But they know better. Agent Denham ushers Braniff to the elevators. ARTHUR BRANIFF (CONT’D) Hi, Jamaal.

dialogues.speaker: DEV ' REAUX
dialogues.text: Mr. Braniff. How was the slammer? Cole notices--

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: Is at his post, but he looks weak, grey, stunned. As he greets residents, his voice is wobbly. Cole crosses, puts his hand on Lester’s arm. Gently:

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Nobody appreciates your staying more than I do, but... I think you need to take a personal day now. Lester wants to protest, but he finally nods. He’s beaten

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. Howard.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: (kindly) You never are going to call me Cole, are you? Lester smiles weakly, shakes his head and goes. Cole watc after him, worried. INT. THE TOWER -- BRANIFF’S PENTHOUSE -- DAY FBI TECHNICIANS wire the place, turning a $45 million apartment into a prison cell. A prison cell with five bedrooms and floor-to-ceiling views of Central Park. A Technician fits Braniff with an ankle bracelet as Agent Denham tours the apartment with his lawyer, MARTY KLEIN.  Middle of 35.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY KLEIN
dialogues.text: My client would like access to the swimming pool downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT DENHAM
dialogues.text: Absolutely not.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY KLEIN
dialogues.text: Then the gym on forty-three.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT DENHAM
dialogues.text: A dim, delusional dream.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY KLEIN
dialogues.text: At least let him have access to the sundeck on fifty. Even death row inmates get fifteen minutes of fresh air a day.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT DENHAM
dialogues.text: Mr. Klein, the rules of your client’s occupancy here are simple: he leaves the apartment for any reason, he gets remanded to federal custody and forfeits his ten million dollars bail. If your client wants fresh air so badly, I suggest he stick his head out a window. Or in an oven. --What is that? the room sits a GREEN AUSTIN-HEALEY TWO-SEATER.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY KLEIN
dialogues.text: Obviously you don’t watch 60 Minutes. That is a 1958 Austin- Healey. Mr. Braniff is a car enthusiast.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT DENHAM
dialogues.text: What’s it doing up here?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR BRANIFF
dialogues.text: (entering, trying out his ankle bracelet like he’s trying on new shoes) We were going to keep it at the Cape, but it gets better mileage here in the city.  36.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lester, still looking weak and grey, painstakingly counts the change for a cup of coffee. When the vendor hands it him, Lester’s hands are shaking so badly that he can bare lift it. INT. ARTHUR BRANIFF’S APARTMENT - (CONTINUATION OF PREVIO

dialogues.speaker: SCENE
dialogues.text: Marty Klein is admiring the Austin Healy. He and Braniff chat affably as if nothing had happened.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY KLEIN
dialogues.text: Aahhhh, this was the one you snaked Mallya out of! How’d you get it up here?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR BRANIFF
dialogues.text: Very carefully. And I made him throw in his best bottle of Latour. Marty Klein crosses to the Braniffs’ WINE REFRIGERATOR, t out a BOTTLE of CHATEAU LATOUR, ‘61, looks at the DISTINC TOWER on the label, whistles. Braniff grabs it back.

dialogues.speaker: BRANIFF
dialogues.text: No you don’t. That’s for my 60th.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT DENHAM
dialogues.text: Well, we’1ll have to confiscate it. Along with all these paintings. Braniff looks to Marty Klein.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY KLEIN
dialogues.text: Everything in this apartment is the legal property of Mrs. Braniff. Consequently none of it is subject to your seizure warrant, Agent Denham.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT DENHAM
dialogues.text: (no rollover) Yeah. She’s a blinking, innocent fawn. INT. LESTER’S APARTMENT - NIGHT Lester slowly comes into the room, shell shocked. He sits his bed, takes off his hat. He looks at the pictures of h TWO GRANDKIDS. For whom he can now provide -- nothing.  37.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She considers Braniff, oddly sanguine given the circumstances. How can he be under house arrest and seem unconcerned? Cole enters with the Sentry Agent.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT DENHAM
dialogues.text: Mr. Howard, thank you for joining us. Cole is staring at the Austin Martin. He can’t believe it

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR BRANIFF
dialogues.text: Beauty, huh? This was the first model off the line, made a present to Winston Churchill shortly before his death. Agent Denham can’t believe this guy is going on about his like nothing’s happened. She snaps at him:

dialogues.speaker: AGENT DENHAM
dialogues.text: Mr. Howard is not here for a car show. (to Cole) I wanted to bring you up to speed on some restrictions to Mr. Braniff’s stay here. (Cole nods) Mr. Braniff may receive no visitors without authorization from my office and a federal officer present. That includes family members, Mr. Klein here, even your staff. Any mail incoming or outgoing must be vetted by my office. Also, you should prepare your staff for an onslaught of food deliveries: the Braniffs will be eating in for the foreseeable future. Questions? Cole doesn’t have any. He stares at the opulence of the Austin Martin, then back at Braniff, who remains cool as cucumber.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR BRANIFF
dialogues.text: I have one. What if there’s a fire?

dialogues.speaker: AGENT DENHAM
dialogues.text: Then I’1l know there’s a god.  38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole and Denham ride down together. In silence. At first.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Thanks for taking my call last night.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT DENHAM
dialogues.text: You're welcome. No more one in the morning, okay.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: You were up.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT DENHAN
dialogues.text: Even so. A silence.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: I was anxious about--

dialogues.speaker: AGENT DENHAM
dialogues.text: --your people, I know. And I’m glad I could help. I want my pound of flesh, though. Cole blinks at her. Then gets it.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Oh! A favor back! Sure, sure.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT DENHAM
dialogues.text: What did you think I meant?

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: I-- never mind. She smiles at him wryly.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT DENHAM
dialogues.text: Please. When would you find the time? The elevator doors open and they enter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole escorts Agent Denham across the lobby.  39.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: I have... (realizing how little) -..some time...

dialogues.speaker: AGENT DENHAM
dialogues.text: Look, I get the 17 hour day thing. I’m in your tribe. She gives him an understanding smile as she says this tha might hint at something personal...? He appraises her.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Warmth? Understanding? (cut the shit) Uh-uh. What do you want? She unapologetically launches in.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT DENHAM
dialogues.text: Look, we still don’t completely have everything clear about Braniff.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Ahhh. You think I might know something. She does. DING! The doors open on the lobby.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT DENHAM
dialogues.text: Outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole sees Agent Denham to her sedan. She stops, peers up (way up) at the penthouse.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT DENHAM
dialogues.text: We’ve accounted for every dime Braniff took, all his holdings, everything he owns. The math doesn’t jive. Somewhere he’s stashed twenty mil.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: (facetious) Where? In his apartment? She just shoots him a look. Yeah. Maybe.  40.

dialogues.speaker: COLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Um... you people are pretty thorough. You don’t think you would have found it?

dialogues.speaker: AGENT DENHAM
dialogues.text: Man swindled sixty billion. You tell me. And it’s all he’s got now. If I were him, I'd keep it close. So if you think of anything we might have missed... She hands him a card: “Jillian Denham, FBI.” Cole reads i

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: I have your number, remember? She remembers, slightly flustered.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT DENHAM
dialogues.text: Yeah... how did you get that?

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: In my business, the stuff you are asked to find at four in the morning...? (shrugs ) It’s a simple phone number.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT DENHAM
dialogues.text: A classified phone number. He ducks the barb, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Are you sorry? A beat. She smiles back at him -- a nice smile -- and goe Cole watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We HOLD ON LESTER’S ANTIQUATED ANSWERING MACHINE, which clicks on. COLE’S VOICE Hey, Lester. This is, “Mr. Howard,” I... I’m thinking about you tonight and I’m in your neighborhood and thought maybe we could grab a quick dinner or something... you there?  41.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole is, in fact, still in midtown, heading downtown, in brutal traffic, but concerned enough about Lester to tell that white lie. He is on his cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Lester, please pick up if you’re there. I’m getting a little... He looks into the phone. This isn’t right. Not at all. COLE (CONT’D) (to the driver) Yeah, DIRECTLY THROUGH TIMES SQUARE?! There’s a good rush hour solution! C’mon--! INT. LESTER’S APARTMENT -- EVENING Empty and quiet. No sign of Lester. KNOCK-KNOCK-KNOCK. COLE’S VOICE Lester? You home? It’s Mr. Howard. It’s Cole, open up. INT. HALLWAY -- OUTSIDE LESTER’S FRONT DOOR -- CONTINUOUS Cole waits for a response. Nothing. He runs his fingers atop the doorframe, then checks under the mat. No key. Not expecting much, he tries the door. To his surprise, i UNLOCKED. INT. LESTER’S APARTMENT -- CONTINUOUS Cole enters. Scours a living room. No sign of Lester. Continues into a BEDROOM. And there he is, lying atop his bed, sound sleep. Cole le out a sigh of relief.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Jeez, Lest, you gave me a scare. (he doesn’t rouse) Lester...c’mon, wake up... Cole goes to his bedside. The man’s out. On his beside table: two empty vials of pills. Cole grabs at a phone --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN AMBULANCE speeds to an ER, Cole’s town car following.  42.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Nurse leads Cole through.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: -- we're really supposed to keep him under observation at least forty-eight hours but as you can see we need the bedspace. Legally we can’t release him on his own accord so either you’1ll have to sign for him or we can call whatever family he’s got --

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: -- no: nobody tells his kids --

dialogues.speaker: ER RESIDENT
dialogues.text: Then he’s all yours. She points him to Lester, on a hospital gurney, alive and conscious. Chin dabbled with grey matter, remnants of the charcoal solution used to pump his stomach. Cole approach

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Hey, Lester. How ya feeling? Lester, ashamed, turns his head away. Cole makes a decisi

dialogues.speaker: COLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Whatyasay you come stay at my place for the holiday?

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: Don’t wanna put you to any more bother.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Lester. This is kind of maybe a good moment to put yourself first...? Come on... please... Why’d you do it?

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: I lost all my money. Everything I saved, everything I set aside.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Your 401K wasn’t everything, was it?  43.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: Nah, nah... but it was doing so good I gave my savings to Mr. Braniff too.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: (that brings him up short) Your savings? All your other money? (Lester nods) When?

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: ‘Bout a month ago.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: And he took it? All your savings? Lester nods, feeling ashamed. Cole reels, appalled.

dialogues.speaker: COLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lester, you mind if I step out a while? I gotta check on a few things back at the Tower.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, Mr. Howard. I’m not gonna try anything dumb again. Don’t want to let you down. Cole can’t believe the man’s loyalty. He swallows his bil and goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the elevators, Dev slips an ENVELOPE into the hands of excessively burly UKRANIAN GENTLEMEN. They look strangely out of place at the Towers.

dialogues.speaker: DEV ' REAUX
dialogues.text: Okay, so are we good? The two men look at each other and almost laugh with disd DEV’REAUX (CONT’D) I mean, in a minimal way, good -- I know we're not good good, but we’re not at a punishing place, either.... The men turn and walk away without a word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DEV’REAUX (CONT’D) I’ll get more next week. (as they’re out of earshot) From fuck-all knows where. Charlie spies Cole marching in, furious, beelining toward elevators.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (‘what the hell’) You forget something? Cole just blasts on by, intent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole joins Fitzhugh aboard Dev’s car.

dialogues.speaker: DEV ' REAUX
dialogues.text: Mr. Howard, what are you --

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Shut up, Dev. Take ‘er up. They start up. Straight at Fitzhugh, intent:

dialogues.speaker: COLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're finance. What do you know about all this Braniff bullshit? Fitzhugh blinks, shocked by Cole’s vehemence.

dialogues.speaker: FITZHUGH
dialogues.text: Well... when I still, ah, had an office to go to we talked about him... I mean, the returns were too good...

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: When did he know? That it was all going sideways? When did Braniff know his Ponzi scheme was cooked?

dialogues.speaker: FITZHUGH
dialogues.text: Had to be around Halloween. That’s when he started cashing out his buddies. We all wondered--

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: So any money an investor gave him after that, say a month ago --  45.

dialogues.speaker: FITZHUGH
dialogues.text: -- he was just using it to bail water out of the Titnic. That’s all Cole needs to hear. He turns to Dev resolutely

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Penthouse. The doors open on Fitzhugh’s floor. Dev looks to him.

dialogues.speaker: DEV ' REAUX
dialogues.text: Fourteen.

dialogues.speaker: FITZHUGH
dialogues.text: Oh, no, I want to see this. INT. THE TOWER -- BRANIFF’S PENTHOUSE -- NIGHT Susan Braniff swigs vodka and pencils a crossword, scratc her shitsu’s ears. Arthur Braniff pumps his legs (ankle bracelet-clad) atop a stationary bicycle, watching TV.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN BRANIFF
dialogues.text: Hon-eeee? What do you want tonight? Le Bernadin takeout? Life in prison when you’re a billionaire. Then: the door the elevator anteroom: POUND-POUND-POUND! Susan jolts up. Braniff stops pedaling and, sweat-soaked, answers the doo There stand (in order of proximity) Cole, Fitzhugh, and D Braniff detects an air of hostility.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR BRANIFF
dialogues.text: C’mon in, fellas. They enter in order, Fitzhugh introducing himself.

dialogues.speaker: FITZHUGH
dialogues.text: Hi, remember me--? Chase Fitzhugh, 14E. Used to be a big fan.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR BRANIFF
dialogues.text: So...what brings you guys up here? Cole knows I’m not supposed to have visitors without supervision. Everyone turns to Cole. Who remains silent. Seething. ARTHUR BRANIFF (CONT’D) Can I fix you a drink? Some of you look like you could use one.  46.

dialogues.speaker: DEV ' REAUX
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’1l take a --

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: We won't be here that long. Braniff senses a torrent coming on. He turns to his wife.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR BRANIFF
dialogues.text: Susan, why don’t you leave us for a spell? I have a feeling Cole will speak his mind more freely without a lady present --

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: I don’t give a flying fuck what I say in front of your wife. She lies down with a dog, she’s got fleas, too. Wow. That blows everyone’s hair back a little.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR BRANIFF
dialogues.text: (his good humor exhausted) Say what you're gonna say.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: You took Lester’s money.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR BRANIFF
dialogues.text: Yes I did. He came to me, asked me to invest it, I had no idea --

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: It was everything he had. Fitzhugh picks up on the emotion in Cole’s voice.

dialogues.speaker: FITZHUGH
dialogues.text: What happened to Lester? Cole studies Braniff’s face, monitoring it as he answers:

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: He took an overdose of sleeping pills this morning. Dev and Fitzhugh both react, gut-punched. It’s harder to tell how Braniff feels: is his concern genuine?

dialogues.speaker: BRANIFF
dialogues.text: Ah, Jesus.  47.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: I got one question for you. Do you care?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR BRANIFF
dialogues.text: What do you mean, do I care --

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: -- do you feel any responsibility, any remorse for what happened to Lester --

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR BRANIFF
dialogues.text: -- as I was saying, I had no idea we were going to lose everything, of course I feel badly --

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: -- THEN WHY HAVEN’T YOU ASKED ME WHETHER HE’S ALIVE OR DEAD? Cole’s caught him. And for a moment he detects Braniff acknowledge it. That does it. Cole looks around, sees what he needs, goes it. <A fireplace poker. He snatches it up, as a weapon.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN BRANIFF
dialogues.text: Oh my god! I’m calling security!

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: I am security! He’s off to the next room, and Dev and Fitzhugh bolt to c up with him. When they do, Cole is facing down -- -- the 1958 Austin-Healey. He steps up to the plate, draw back the fireplace poker and WHACK! A headlight goes flyi Braniff arrives, cringes at the destruction.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR BRANIFF
dialogues.text: Ah, Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Now he cares... WHACK! There goes the other headlight.

dialogues.speaker: FITZHUGH
dialogues.text: Cole, that’s an Austin-Healey! They don’t make those anymore.  48.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Not like doormen. They make new ones of those all the time.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: And the people who PARK YOUR CARS (whack!) and SHINE YOUR SHOES?! I’m sure they'll have no trouble REPLACING (whack!) their LIFE

dialogues.speaker: SAVINGS
dialogues.text: DEV’ REAUX (fuck it) Shit, lemme have a swing!

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR BRANIFF
dialogues.text: Susan!! Call the FBI!!

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Don’t bother. I’m done here. That’s not quite true. He takes one last WHACK at the windshield, spiderwebbing it, then tosses the fire poker aside like he’s hit a walk-off homer. IN THE LIVING ROOM, Susan Braniff is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN BRANIFF
dialogues.text: -- yes, he’s here right now. He’s destroying the place -- Cole enters, finds the phone line, rips it from the wall.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: I‘1l send a man up in the morning to fix that. He exits. Followed by Fitzhugh and Dev’reaux.

dialogues.speaker: FITZHUGH
dialogues.text: Folks. Pleasure meeting you.

dialogues.speaker: DEV ' REAUX
dialogues.text: (as he closes the door) Merry Christmas, everybody. Off Susan Braniff, stunned, and Arthur Braniff, pissed -- DEV’REAUX (0.S.CONT’D) (CONT'D) (through the door) Now this is one HELL of a building!  49.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holiday revelers sing karaoke and get hammered at the bar the back, Cole, Dev’reaux, Fitzhugh and Charlie huddle in booth; the mood here is funereal. DEV’ REAUX How do you steal sixty billion dollars?! I mean, nobody sit up after the first ten billion gone and say, whoa! lLet’s change the locks?!

dialogues.speaker: FITZHUGH
dialogues.text: The bigger the lie, the more brazen you are telling it, the more people’1ll buy it. That’s what they taught us at Wharton. (to Cole) You talk to Lester? He doing alright? Cole nods, lost in his thoughts. Charlie notes his demean

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Cole? You okay? There are other jobs, you know. Cole’s not listening. Charlie, Fitz and Dev exchange glances, worried. Then:

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: How much you guys know about interior design?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: That’s not a career for these times! Those guys are working for food!

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Something funny about the Braniff place. Remember they hired that hot-shot designer..? And he ripped everything up...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A major redo. Hard hats tear up floors and knock down wal as a MALE INTERIOR DESIGNER walks the job with Cole, gesticulating at his work.  50.

dialogues.speaker: COLE, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: He went around yammering about how much he hated walls, and how everything had to be open, open, open...? So... They pass a WALL in the middle of the living room.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: -- why’d they leave that one wall dead in the middle of the place? Charlie stares at Cole.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You're fired from your job in the worst economy since the dust bowl and that’s what’s on your mind? A wall? Cole doesn’t answer. His mind is going a mile a minute. H turns to Fitzhugh.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Your living room has the same lay- out as Braniff’s, right? (Fitz nods) Your kids in bed yet?

dialogues.speaker: FITZHUGH
dialogues.text: (this is awkward) They’re asleep. They’re not in bed. INT. THE TOWER -- FITZHUGH’S APARTMENT -- NIGHT The four men tip-toe into Fitzhugh’s apartment. It’s dark but everyone can see: what used to be a cozily-appointed is now nearly empty, almost totally bereft of furniture.

dialogues.speaker: FITZHUGH
dialogues.text: The mortgage obviously came first... we had to downscale... (despite his brave face, he’s torn up over this) I think my wife’s hiding back there... she'll be embarrassed I’ve got people over. Doesn’t want you to see the sleeping bags... I’m just gonna kiss them goodnight...  51. He goes. Cole moves to the wall matching the one in Braniff’s place. He starts tapping along it.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Cole, what are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Checking if this wall is load- bearing.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I know, I mean: what are you doing checking if it’s load-bearing? Clunk. A hollow sound. Cole taps all around it. Smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DEV ' REAUX
dialogues.text: What’d you find?

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Space. Braniff knocked down every unnecessary wall but this one. Why do you think he did that? Charlie moves close enough to Cole to whisper:

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Would you tell me what's going through your head?

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: No. INT. THE TOWER -- COLE’S OFFICE -- NIGHT Cole goes through old records in the middle of the night. Finds the file he’s looking for, withdraws it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The square is awash with New Yorkers and tourists alike, bundled up in holiday garb. Cole stands waiting by Pulitz Fountain. Then, across the square -- -- Jillian Denham arrives. In civilian clothes and all the more attractive it, so we will now refer to her as JILLIAN.

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Thank you for meeting me. I hope I didn’t take you away from anything.  52.

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN
dialogues.text: Nothing I’d want a second date with. You?

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Just a houseguest.

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN
dialogues.text: We heard. Lester feeling better? (Cole nods) We also heard about your run-in with Braniff. You know, you violated three federal laws by going up there. (beat) Because of that, a lot of people down at the bureau want to buy you a drink.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Does that include you? She smiles. INT. ELAINE’S - NIGHT Jillian and Cole are midway through a couple of martinis, which are tasting very, very good about now. The paper wi the layout of Braniff’s penthouse is rolled out in front them.

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN
dialogues.text: You really think the 20 million is here?

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: There’s no other place it could be. They knocked down every non-load- bearing wall in the place except one. (withdraws more evidence, a Tower sign-in sheet) Here -- see? A delivery and installation to Braniff’s penthouse from an “H&J Security.” They sell and install safes. (taps the layout wall) I think there’s a safe in this wall. Like you said: if you had that much money, you’d keep it close. She scours the layout, intrigued. Then, looks away.  53.

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: No, look, I think it’s there--

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN
dialogues.text: No -- I bet you're right.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Then why “shit?”

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN
dialogues.text: (hands the layout back) You never showed me this.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN
dialogues.text: I didn’t hear any of this. Cole studies her now: is she joking? No.

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Word came down yesterday. The bureau is officially hands-off as far as Arthur Braniff is concerned.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: (aghast) What do you mean “hands off"? You’re not going to prosecute?

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN
dialogues.text: No, it’s too public to do nothing, but... they’1ll make a deal, he’1ll give up a few cohorts and they’1l all do a little time. Not hard time mind you, a year maybe ina club fed.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: After everything he’s done? Who in the hell would want to protect that--

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN
dialogues.text: We think Braniff has files on people, some very rich, very powerful people. We have strict orders: Do-Not-Touch. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So whether it’s in a safe in that wall or in a helium balloon over Tribecca, he’s gonna walk away from all this with a twenty million dollar parachute.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: You're kidding me.

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN
dialogues.text: I was funny once. (re the drink) Want another one?

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: I, ah, I never have seconds.

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN
dialogues.text: Moderation in all things. Probably wise. Cole plays with his swizzle stick for a moment, then sudd slaps his palm down on the bar. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: And look where it’s gotten me! Grade-grubbing, student loans, trainee programs, years and years, every i dotted, every t crossed, every form filled out, punctual, loyal, crossing on green, waiting on red, inching my way up bit by bit, grovel by grovel, to some kind of white collar “security” that’s never secure... because I’m not one of them!!

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. The rich are very, very clubby. They look out for each other. And no one else.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: They don’t know us, they don’t see us, they don’t think about us -- His head comes up. Suddenly, under his breath: COLE (CONT’D) They’d never see us coming.  55.

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN
dialogues.text: Oh, no, no, no, whatever you just said, I did not hear.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Oh, but you know what I-- She covers her ears like a child:

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN
dialogues.text: La la la! I can’t hear you! I can’t hear you! La la la la! She shoots him a sly look, though. He laughs.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: And I thought I wasn’t going to like you for not hearing things. She smiles at him. Cole pays the check.

dialogues.speaker: COLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well... it’s been eye-opening. They get up off their stools, friends now. He’s still thinking, a mile a minute.

dialogues.speaker: COLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Too bad I’m banned from the building for life.

dialogues.speaker: JILLIAN
dialogues.text: I’m sure Mr. Simon felt that way. Until he started thinking about finding someone who knows every inch of that building from the tiniest crack in the mortar to the steel in the beams, the name of every resident, who keeps his mouth shut about where the bodies are buried, doesn’t complain, moves like lightening and makes everyone around him look good -- ONE DAY BEFORE CHRISTMAS. Cole blinks. He hadn’t thought about it in exactly that light. INT. THE TOWER -- BRANIFF’S PENTHOUSE -- MONDAY MORNING Arthur Braniff pours coffee from a sterling silver pot an offers it to Cole, who declines.  56. Braniff offers it instead to Mr. Simon, who receives it gladly. They sit around Braniff’s dining room, a picture civility.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR BRANIFF
dialogues.text: Nothing for you, Cole? Water? Cole demurs.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SIMON
dialogues.text: Mr. Braniff, let me say how gracious you’ve been in all this. What happened over the holiday, what Mr. Howard did coming up here, was wholly inexcusable. It’s a testament to your generosity, sir, that he is allowed on the premises.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR BRANIFF
dialogues.text: It’s a trying time for everyone. I don’t blame anybody for losing their cool given what they’ve been hearing in the press. And Mr. Howard’s too valuable an asset to the building to lose over a silly flare-up. I’m sure he regrets what he did. Braniff smiles at Cole, which nearly sets him off. But to Cole’s keeping his cool.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SIMON
dialogues.text: Mr. Howard volunteered to come here this morning to apologize, in the hopes we might put this unseemly incident behind us. Mr. Howard? Everyone faces Cole. Braniff. Mrs. Braniff, standing guardedly in a doorway. Even Jillian, here to monitor the visit. Cole chooses his words carefully.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Mr. Braniff, I deeply regret what transpired between us last week. If I could go back, I’d behave much differently. Please know that my estimation of your character hasn’t wavered a bit throughout this ordeal, and that today I hold you in the same respect I always have. To Mr. Simon's ears this sounds like the proper kowtowing But Braniff knows: Cole is saying go-fuck-yourself.  57.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR BRANIFF
dialogues.text: And let me say that I know your job’s tough. I mean, resentments are bound to bubble up when you feel sometimes like a... a glorified servant. He says this affably, but it is giant FUCK YOU back to Co

dialogues.speaker: MR. SIMON
dialogues.text: As for Mr. Braniff’s automobile? Cole’s eyes briefly flit to “The Wall,” then back to Bran He’s made his decision.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Sir, I will pay you back for all the damage that’s been done. And Braniff knows what Cole means: I’m coming for you. An it kind of makes him smile. Hey-ho, let’s go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lines and lines of Chinese immigrants sewing this year’s fashions for three dollars-an-hour. Sweatshop, U.S.A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The factory MANAGER, a diminutive Chinese man, plays look at the door. A PAIR OF HANDS massages an office safe’s di To the right: click-click-click. To the left: clack-clack clack. Then: click-clack-click. The hands belong to SLIDE LINDUS. Cole’s childhood friend

dialogues.speaker: SLIDE
dialogues.text: Open says me. The safe complies. The Manager pushes Slide aside to get inside the safe but first Slide plucks up a band of cash within. The Manager protests in Cantonese but...

dialogues.speaker: SLIDE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ah-ah-ah-ah. Don’t even think about paying me in merchandise. You ain’t got nothing my size.  58.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slide rides down surrounded by Chinese seamstresses, a go foot-and-a-half taller than the bunch. He smiles at them.

dialogues.speaker: SLIDE
dialogues.text: Any you ladies a masseuse? (his cell RINGS; he reacts to the ID and picks up) Old King Cole, you merry old soul, why are you admitting you know me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slide enters the restaurant, approaches Cole in a booth n a window.
